Ni catalysts derived from the carbothermal reduction of nickel phyllosilicate were investigated and their application in the hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) was revealed. The most effective catalyst (S3M1.5@NiPS-600) was prepared by using a sucrose-melamine mixture (molar ratio = 2:1) as the reducing agent with a proper thermal treatment (maintained at 600 °C for 2 h). By using S3M1.5@NiPS-600, a high GVL productivity (1387 mmol GVL/g surface Ni/h), good recyclability (4.9% loss of initial activity in five cycles), and a negligible deactivation rate were observed. The promising outcome was attributed to grafted carbon and nitrogen species on the carbothermally reduced Ni/SiO2 catalyst. Grafted carbon species improve catalyst stability whereas immobilized nitrogen species induce Niδ+ (δ>2) with a strong Lewis acidity. Paired Niδ+ and Ni0 sites are active in the reduction of the ketone group of LA, thereby enhancing the production of GVL. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbothermal reduction Hydrogenation Levulinic acid Nickel phyllosilicate Nitrogen 1 Introduction Nickel phyllosilicates (NiPS) are minerals composed of continuous SiO4 tetrahedral sheets linked to NiO2 octahedral sheets [1]. NiPS can be synthesized with 1:1 and 2:1 ratios of tetrahedra to octahedra, formed with different morphologies (lamellar-, tubular-, and core-sheath-types [2]), and hybridized with other oxides (e.g., NiPS-supported cerium oxides [3]). Owing to its unique structure, porosity, and stability, NiPS can be applied in numerous fields such as drug delivery [4], lithium batteries [5], and supercapacitors [6]. An important application of NiPS is to be the precursor of silica-supported Ni catalysts, which are used in reactions such as water-gas shift [7], methane partial oxidation [8], and methane dry reforming [2]. Through a reduction treatment in H2, Ni2+ in octahedra can be extracted (exsolution) to form Ni0 nanoparticles (NPs) supported on silica. The complete reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0 NPs is difficult at temperatures below 700 °C [9]. Intriguingly, the advantages of using partially reduced NiPS are frequently reported because of their unique superficial sites, such as acidic hydroxyls and coordinatively unsaturated Ni2+ species. Zhang et al. [10] found that the hydroxyls of partially reduced NiPS promoted Ni dispersion and suppressed coke deposition in ethanol steam reforming. Kong et al. [11] discovered the synergy of metal (Ni0 NPs) and acid (coordinatively unsaturated Ni2+) in the hydrogenolysis of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to furanic compounds. The advantage of the metal-support interaction of NiPS-derived catalysts in suppressing Ni0 NPs sintering has been reported [12]. However, reducing NiPS in H2 to prepare Ni/SiO2 catalysts has some drawbacks. A dilemma is that the destruction/reorganization of NiPS structure is inevitable to extract Ni2+ cations from the octahedron during H2 reduction. This buries extracted Ni species in collapsed structures and limits the diffusion of reactants and products. For example, approximately four-fold decreases of the surface area (98.7 m2/g) and pore volume (0.17 cm3/g) of NiPS-derived catalyst were reported compared to those of its pristine (352.5 m2/g and 0.76 cm3/g) after H2 reduction [11]. Carbothermal reduction (using carbon sources as reducing agents) has been used in sponge iron preparation from iron oxide and in the reduction of transitional metal oxides (e.g., NiO, Cu2O, and ZnO) [13]. Autocatalytic transformation of metal oxides to their metallic forms has been known, and mechanisms such as intermediate CO-induced reduction, gaseous metal carbide reduction, and thermal dissociation have been proposed [14]. Although a definite mechanism is still unresolved, carbothermal reduction is promising for the synthesis of novel composites such as LiFePO4/C (a cathode material for lithium-ion batteries) [15] and C/FeS/Fe (an adsorbent of Cr4+) [16]. To the best of our knowledge, carbothermal reduction to prepare reduced Ni catalysts from NiPS has not been explored. Levulinic acid (LA) is one of the chemical opportunities from carbohydrates. Simple and cost-effective processes of LA production have already been practiced, e.g., the acid-hydrolysis process of Biofine [17]. This enables LA to be a potential platform chemical. Hydrogenation of LA to γ-valerolactone (GVL) is a biorefining process. Upgrading low-value LA to valuable GVL is a renewable route for the preparation of fuel additives, food ingredients, and green solvents [18]. Ru/C is a benchmark catalyst for LA hydrogenation to GVL [18, 19]. However, the challenges of Ru leaching, sintering, and costly Ru prices remain to be overcome [20]. The potential catalyst for the industrial practice of LA hydrogenation to GVL should be non-precious metal/metal oxide-based with good stability [21]. This has stimulated recent studies on the design of transient metal-based catalysts, particularly Ni, in the hydrogenation of LA [22, 23]. For example, Shimizu group [24] designed an attractive Ni–MoOx/C catalyst that showed a turnover number (TON) 300 times higher than that of other non-noble catalysts and an equivalent TON value as that of Ru/C. Nandi et al. [25] showed that core-shell structured Ni0 NPs had an outstanding GVL yield (99%) with a full LA conversion at a relatively low temperature (100 °C) and pressure (ca. 34 bar). Ni-metal alloys [26, 27] and Ni phosphide [28] catalysts were also effective in LA hydrogenation. In this study, NiPS-derived catalysts through carbothermal reduction [14] using sucrose and sucrose-melamine mixture as the reducing agents were firstly synthesized, and their application in LA hydrogenation was reported. Proper reduction conditions, including carbothermal temperature, amount of carbon loading, and the ratio of the sucrose-melamine mixture, were revealed. The sucrose-melamine mixture was more appropriate than H2 and sucrose as the reducing agent to transform NiPS into a C- and N-coated Ni/SiO2 catalyst. The high productivity was attributed to the strong Lewis acidic Niδ+ (δ>2) species induced by N decoration. Paired Niδ+ and Ni0 were proposed to be highly active in the reduction of LA. The good stability was ascribed to the grafted carbonaceous species which inhibited acid and water attacks. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Ammonia solution (28%, SHOWA), Ni(NO3)2•6H2O (99.999%, Sigma-Aldrich), colloidal silica (LUDOX HS30, Sigma-Aldrich), sucrose (99%, SHOWA), and melamine (99%, Alfa-Aesar) were used as received. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis NiPS was synthesized by using the ammonia evaporation hydrothermal method [29]. A modified facile hydrothermal method was used to graft sucrose or a sucrose-melamine mixture on NiPS [30]. Briefly, 0.5 g of NiPS was mixed with 0.52 g (1.5 mmol), 1.04 g (3.0 mmol), or 1.55 g (4.5 mmol) of sucrose in deionized water (60 mL). Each mixture was stirred until the sucrose was completely dissolved at 60 °C. The resultant solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined hydrothermal bomb and kept at 175 °C for 12 h. The NiPS with hydrothermally grafted sucrose is denoted as Sx/NiPS (x = 1.5, 3, or 4.5). To reveal the effect of N decoration, a designated amount of melamine was mixed with sucrose (the molar ratio of melamine to sucrose was set at 0.1, 0.3, or 0.5) and 0.5 g NiPS in deionized water (60 mL), and subjected to the same hydrothermal treatment mentioned above (i.e., SxMy/NiPS, y = 0.15, 0.3, 0.45, 0.75, 0.9, 1.5, 1.35, or 2.25). The brownish precursor (Sx/NiPS or SxMy/NiPS) was carbonized in a tubular furnace at 500, 600, or 700 °C in a nitrogen stream (70 mL/min) for 2 h. The yielded catalyst was denoted as SxMy@NiPS suffixed with its carbonized temperature. The catalyst was transferred to the reactor in an N2-filled glove bag for activity evaluation. Hydrogen-reduced NiPS (NiPS-H2–600, treated at 600 °C in a 10% H2/N2 stream for 2 h) was also synthesized for comparison. 2.3 Characterization Crystallinity was analyzed by a powder X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku D/Max-IIB) using a Cu Kα radiation source. In situ X-ray absorption spectrum at the Ni K-edge was recorded in transmission mode at beamline TLS-17C1 of the National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Taiwan. An in situ cell with temperature/gas flow control was used to reduce the passivated catalyst (kept isothermal at 250 °C for 10 min) to remove the thin film of NiO made by passivation. After cooling to room temperature, the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum was collected in an H2 environment. The measurement of Raman spectroscopy was performed on the ProMaker system (Protrustech Corporation) equipped with a CCD detector. An excitation laser with its wavelength of 532 nm and 1 mW power was used. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) were performed with a Q600 TGA system (TA Instruments). A quadruple mass spectrometer (Thermostar GSD 320, Pfeiffer Vacuum) was coupled via a heated line to the TGA to measure the volatile species produced during pyrolysis. Detected ions included m/z = 2, 15, 16, 18, and 44 by using ultra-high N2 as the sweeper gas (50 mL/min). The bulk composition was acquired by an inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, Kontron S-35) and an elemental analyzer (Elementar vario EL cube). An AutoChem II (Micromeritics) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector was used to record the profiles of temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR), CO pulse titration, and temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) of tested catalysts. Porosity was estimated by using the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms obtained from an automated surface analyzer (Micromeritics ASAP 2020). Ni0 NPs were observed by a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100F Electron Microscope). The elemental distribution of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 was observed by TEM–energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) mapping. The measurement of Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR, Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50) of the pyridine-adsorbed catalyst was conducted in an in situ quartz cell (transmission mode, Dalian Xuanyu Technology). The passivated sample was reduced at 250 °C for 10 min, cooled to 150 °C, and then exposed to pyridine vapor. Excess pyridine was extracted at 150 °C under a vacuum of 1.2 × 10–3 Pa for 1 h. The temperature-resolved pyridine desorption spectra were recorded from 150 °C to 390 °C by using a 10 °C/min ramping rate. The X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) was performed on a K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific) with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV). The binding energy was calibrated by using the C 1 s signal at 284.8 eV as the reference. 2.4 Hydrogenation test Hydrogenation test was performed in a batch-type stainless steel reactor (Parr model 4561). 0.1 g of carbonized catalyst (80–40 mesh; 0.177–0.42 mm) was mixed with 0.3 g of LA and 60 mL of ethyl acetate (solvent), and 5 mL dodecane (internal standard) in the N2-filled glove bag and then sealed in the batch reactor. The reaction temperature was set at 150, 170, 190, and 210 °C for activation energy analysis. GVL was the main product with trace 4-hydroxyvaleric acid (< 1%) and undetectable angelica lactone, indicating hydrogenation-dehydration route was dominated [18]. The carbon balance of each trial was greater than 95%. An agitating rate of 300 rpm was used. The reactor was purged with N2 (100 mL/min) for 10 min three times before the test. The system was then pressurized with H2 to the designated pressure (10 bar for activity evaluation and 20, 30, 40, and 50 bar for kinetic analysis) at room temperature. After attending the reaction temperature, the autogenous pressures were 16 bar for activity evaluation and 28, 40, 48, and 60 bar for kinetic analysis under isobaric conditions. Internal and external diffusional resistances were evaluated by different catalyst particle sizes and agitating rates (see Figure S1) and both resistances were trivial. Details of NiPS synthesis, characterization, evaluations of internal and external diffusion resistances, and catalytic tests were reported in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Carbothermal reduction of NiPS Fig. 1(a) shows the XRD patterns of S3/NiPS and S3M1.5/NiPS caramelized at 500, 600, and 700 °C. Passivated NiPS-H2–600 was also analyzed. The broad responses of NiPS at 26.7°, 33.7°, 39.7°, 53.2°, and 60.9° (PDF#43–0664) and the weak signals of the (111), (200), and (220) planes of Ni at 44.4°, 51.8°, and 76.4° (PDF#04–0850), respectively, were observed for S3@NiPS-500 and S3M1.5@NiPS-500. This indicated that NiPS structure could be mainly preserved. By increasing the temperature to 600 °C, the diffractions of NiPS vanished and the signals of Ni and NiO crystal faces enhanced. Using 700 °C as the caramelization temperature further intensified the diffractions of Ni and NiO. The Scherrer formula-estimated Ni crystallite size by using the Ni (111) diffraction was in the range of 3.5 to 8.5 nm. To reveal the local geometry of Ni species, in situ EXAFS spectra of passivated catalysts after reducing in H2 were recorded. This treatment allows passivation-made NiO film to be reduced without deep reduction (see the H2-TPR profiles of NiPS and passivated NiPS-H2–600 in Figure S2). Fig. 1(b) exhibits the radial distribution functions (RDFs) obtained from Fourier transformation (without phase correction) of k3-weighted EXAFS data and the fitted curves and Table 1 lists the derived structural parameters. Ni foil, NiPS, and NiPS-H2–600 were also analyzed. The RDF profile of NiPS displayed two peaks at approximately 2.06 Å (Ni-O shell) and 3.09 Å (Ni-Ni / Ni-Si shell). The coordination number (CN) value of the first Ni-O shell is close to 6, suggesting a hexa-coordinated Ni ion in an octahedron of NiPS. The backscattering contributions of Ni-Ni (3.07 Å) of neighboring octahedral Ni2+ and Ni-Si (3.27 Å) of (SiO4)4– could not be differentiated, and were lumped and fitted with the Ni-Ni scattering path. For the RDF profile of NiPS-H2–600, a new peak appeared at approximately 2.48 Å, associating with the Ni-Ni bond of metallic Ni [31]. The RDF profiles of S3@NiPS-500 and S3M1.5@NiPS-500 seemed to be in a transitional form between those of NiPS and Ni foil. The RDF profile of S3@NiPS-600, S3M1.5@NiPS-600, S3@NiPS-700, or S3M1.5@NiPS-700 was similar to those of Ni foil and NiPS-H2–600, displaying a strong response of Ni-Ni shell of metallic Ni. The CN value of the Ni-O shell decreased following the order as S3M1.5@NiPS-500 (3.49) > S3@NiPS-500 (3.47) > NiPS-H2–600 (1.89) > S3M1.5@NiPS-600 (1.71) > S3@NiPS-600 (0.81) > S3M1.5@NiPS-700 (0.38) > S3@NiPS-700 (0.23). Inversely, the CN value of the Ni-Ni shell increased with the order of S3M1.5@NiPS-500 (1.32) < S3@NiPS-500 (2.08) < NiPS-H2–600 (4.64) < S3M1.5@NiPS-600 (6.41) < S3@NiPS-600 (8.75) < S3M1.5@NiPS-700 (9.24) < S3@NiPS-700 (9.72). These trends indicated that (i) the higher the caramelization temperature, the lower the oxidation state of Ni cations and the larger the Ni0 NPs could be; (ii) a higher reduction extent of NiPS and a larger size of Ni0 NPs were obtained by using sucrose as the reducing agent than those by using H2 sucrose-melamine mixture at 600 °C. Raman spectra of carbothermally reduced catalysts were recorded to reveal the structural imperfection of grafted carbonaceous materials (see Fig. 2). Two prominent peaks referred to ideal graphitic (G band, 1586 cm−1) and disordered graphitic lattices (D band, 1350 cm−1) were observed [32, 33]. The ratio of the D and G band intensities (ID/IG) can be used to evaluate the graphitic order of deposited carbonaceous materials. The ID/IG value showed an increasing trend from 0.91 (S3@NiPS-500) to 0.99 (S3@NiPS-700) and from 0.93 (S3M1.5@NiPS-500) to 1.11 (S3M1.5@NiPS-700). Besides, the ID/IG value of the N-doped sample was higher than its un-doped counterpart at the same caramelization temperature. These results underlined that a higher extent of disordered graphite was formed by using a higher caramelization temperature and by introducing a heteroatom, i.e., N [33, 34]. To understand the carbothermal reduction of S3/NiPS and S3M1.5/NiPS, the TGA/DTG profiles together with evolved MS fragments of exhaust gasses were recorded, shown in Fig. 3. S3/SiO2 and S3M1.5/SiO2 were also tested (see Figure S3). Recorded fragments included hydrogen (m/z = 2), methane or ammonia (m/z = 15 and 16), water (m/z = 18), and carbon dioxide (m/z = 44). The DTG profiles of tested samples showed several responses, suggesting multiple reactions occurred. The onset temperatures of exhausted species are in the following order: H2O (< 150 °C) before CH4/CO2 (ca. 200 °C) before H2 (> 350 °C). This implied a sequential process (dehydration → demethylation/decarboxylation → dehydrogenation) of the caramelization of grafted sucrose. For S3M1.5/SiO2 or S3M1.5/NiPS, a DTG peak at approximately 320 °C was identified. This peak could be attributed to the mass loss of desorbed ammonia from the condensation of grafted melamine [35]. The onset temperatures of H2 desorption of S3/NiPS (348 °C) and S3M1.5/NiPS (350 °C) were approximately 100° lower than those of S3/SiO2 (450 °C) and S3M1.5/SiO2 (438 °C). This difference implied that dehydrogenation of grafted sucrose was promoted by NiPS, possibly catalyzed by Ni species [36]. Interestingly, even though H2 was generated during the caramelization of S3/NiPS and S3M1.5/NiPS below 600 °C, the coordination geometry of Ni0 NPs of S3@NiPS-600, S3M1.5@NiPS-600, and NiPS-H2–600 were different (see Table 1). This indicated that the local geometry of Ni0 NPs of NiPS-derived catalyst depends on the reducing agent. 3.2 Evaluation of activity, recyclability, and deactivation rate Fig. 4(a) exhibits the LA conversion and GVL yield of NiPS, S3/NiPS, and S3M1.5/NiPS reduced at different temperatures (i.e., 500 °C, 600 °C, and 700 °C and kept isothermal for 2 h). Higher conversions and yields by using 600 °C as the reduction temperature was observed for NiPS (80.4% and 75.8%) and S3M1.5/NiPS (94.6% and 91.3%) than their counterparts reduced at 500 °C and 700 °C. S3/NiPS showed low conversions (below 25%) and GVL yields (below 20%) regardless of the caramelization temperatures. The catalytic results indicated that using 600 °C is preferred by using either H2 or sucrose-melamine mixture as the reducing agent. Fig. 4(b) shows the LA conversion as a function of the deposited amount of sucrose and the N/C ratio of the melamine-sucrose mixture of the SxMy@NiPS-600 catalysts. The results indicated that hydrogenation activity depends on the amount of grafted sucrose and the N/C ratio. Among tested catalysts, S3M1.5@NiPS-600 is the most active. This evidenced that the amounts of grafted sucrose and melamine are proper in the preparation of Ni/SiO2 catalyst through carbothermal reduction of NiPS. Fig. 5(a) show the recycling tests of NiPS-H2–600 and S3M1.5@NiPS-600. A considerable loss of conversion from 89.6% (the 1st cycle) to 63.2% (the 5th cycle) was seen by using NiPS-H2–600. In contrast, the activity loss of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 was trivial (from 94.1% to 89.5%, a 4.9% loss of initial activity). The amount of leached Ni in the resultant solution was undetectable for each cycle. Moreover, the XRD-estimated crystallite size of Ni (8.0 nm) after five consecutive runs was close to that of its fresh form (6.1 nm, see Figure S4). The stability was further investigated by the deactivation rate analysis, using the variation of LA concentration concerning the product of catalyst weight and reaction time (S = w × t) [37] with two different catalyst masses (w = 0.05 g and 0.1 g). Fig. 5(b) shows the deactivation trends of NiPS-H2–600. The trends of LA concentration dropped sharply at low values of S and then leveled off at S > 20. Moreover, two different masses of NiPS-H2–600 had a wide gap at S values greater than 20. These results indicated that a considerable extent of deactivation occurred. By contrast, the trends of the two curves of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 with different catalyst masses seemed to be unaltered with a narrow gap in the whole range of S value (see Fig. 5(c)), implying a little extent of deactivation. The recycling test and deactivation rate analysis underlined the better stability of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 than that of NiPS-H2–600. The better stability of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 can be attributed to the deposited carbonaceous species after carbothermal reduction. Deposited carbonaceous species can limit the digestion of active site and support caused by acid and water attacks [38, 39]. 3.3 Physicochemical properties of NiPS-H2–600, S3@NiPS-600, and S3M1.5@NiPS-600 To understand why S3M1.5@NiPS-600 had a better performance, its physicochemical properties were thoroughly analyzed and compared with its counterparts. Table 2 lists the elemental compositions. The Ni and Si contents of NiPS-H2–600 were close to their designated values (36.5 wt% Ni and 23.3 wt% Si of Ni3Si4O10(OH)2) [9]. The Ni contents of S3@NiPS-600 and S3M1.5@NiPS-600 were 28.0 wt% and 24.3 wt%, respectively, with the Si contents of ca. 20 wt%. The decreased Ni and Si contents were compensated by C (6.6 wt%) for S3@NiPS-600; the sum of C (9.4 wt%) and N (0.7 wt%), S3M1.5@NiPS-600. The estimated surface concentration of Ni0 NPs (CNi) and its dispersion (DNi) decreased following a descending order as S3M1.5@NiPS-600 (103.5 μmol/g and 2.5%) > NiPS-H2–600 (72.2 μmol/g and 1.2%) > S3@NiPS-600 (9.5 μmol/g and 0.2%). Accordingly, using a sucrose-melamine mixture as the reducing agent is favorable. Table 2 presents the porosities and Figure S5 shows the N2 isotherms and pore size distributions of tested samples. Pristine NiPS had its specific surface area of 350 m2/g and pore volume of 0.88 cm3/g. The NiPS-H2–600 showed approximately a 25% decrease in surface area (264 m2/g) and a 42% decrease in pore volume (0.51 cm3/g), indicating the porous structure was partially damaged. In comparison, S3M1.5@NiPS-600 had a nearly identical surface area (357 m2/g) with a lower decrease (a 33% loss) of pore volume (0.59 cm3/g). The adsorption/desorption curves of each sample showed a type IV isotherm and an H-3 hysteresis loop, suggesting the presence of clay-like slit pores. The similar pore size distribution (2–20 nm) implied that the deposited carbon had little impact on pore blockage. Fig. 6 shows the Ni particles of tested catalysts observed by TEM and the histograms of the particle distribution. The averaged Ni particle sizes increased following the order as NiPS-H2–600 (4.2 nm) < S3M1.5@NiPS-600 (5.7 nm) < S3@NiPS-600 (7.6 nm), in line with the crystallite size estimated by XRD. The images of EDXS mapping of C, N, O, Si, and Ni of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 (see Figure S6) showed that all elements were highly dispersed. Interfaces of Ni and N were identified, suggesting that some Ni and N species were in contact. Fig. 7(a) displays the NH3-TPD profiles. Two or three peaks were observed for tested catalysts. The desorption peak below 200 °C was related to the excess NH3 molecules originated from hydrogen-bonded (NH3)n–NH4+ complexes [40]; the peak at 250–400 °C, acid sites such as acidic hydroxyls and coordinatively unsaturated Ni2+ sites [11]. The bands of pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites (LAS) at 1453 cm−1 and Brønsted acid site (BAS) at 1541 cm−1 were observed [41]. By increasing temperature from 150 to 390 °C, the concentration of LAS decreased from 3.3 to 0.4 μmol/g for NiPS-H2–600, from 3.1 to 0.4 μmol/g for S3@NiPS-600, and from 3.9 to 1.7 μmol/g for S3M1.5@NiPS-600. Fig. 8 shows the XPS spectra of Ni 2p3/2 and N 1 s photolines. The Ni 2p3/2 peak at approximately 855.0 eV with a satellite peak at 862.0 eV is originated from Ni2+ species. Coherently, a downward binding energy shift of N 1 s peak of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 (399.0 eV) was observed compared to that of the solid residue of the sucrose-melamine mixture (400.0 eV) after subjecting to the caramelization at 600 °C. This chemical shift implied that N species accept electrons from neighboring Ni cations, thereby lowering the binding energy of N 1 s response. 3.4 Kinetic analysis Fig. 9(a) and (b) show the kinetic analysis of the effects of LA concentration and H2 pressure and Tables S1 and S2 list the experimental data. The reaction orders derived from the double logarithmic plot of hydrogenation rate for LA concentration were −0.15 (NiPS-H2–600) and 0.03 (S3M1.5@NiPS-600); the orders obtained for H2 pressure, 1.0 (NiPS-H2–600) and 1.5 (S3M1.5@NiPS-600). The values of the slopes were close to zero by varying LA concentration, indicating that LA is strongly adsorbed on NiPS-H2–600 and S3M1.5@NiPS-600. The positive order obtained by varying H2 pressure suggests the dissociation of H2 is rate-limiting [45, 46]. Furthermore, the higher reaction order of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 implied that it was more active in hydrogenation because the rate can be improved more significantly by increasing H2 pressure [47]. 3.5 The synergy of paired Niδ+-Ni0 sites for LA hydrogenation Based on the aforementioned results, we proposed that paired Niδ+-Ni0 sites play a key role in enhancing the reduction of LA. The efficacy of paired Niδ+-Ni0 sites of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 was elucidated by the activation energy analysis and its GVL productivity. The apparent activation energies of LA hydrogenation to GVL over NiPS-H2–600 and S3M1.5@NiPS-600 were derived from the slopes of their respective Arrhenius plots, shown in Figure S7; the experimental data was listed in Table S3. The calculated activation energy of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 (21.0 kJ/mol) was lower than that of NiPS-H2–600 (30.1 kJ/mol) and was less than half of the estimated activation energy of Ru-promoted Ni catalyst (44.1 kJ/mol) [48]. Table S4 presents the productivities of GVL of Ni catalysts in recent studies. A high GVL productivity (1387 mmol GVL/g surface Ni/h) was achieved by using S3M1.5@NiPS-600 in a comparatively milder reaction condition than most catalysts. These results emphasize the potential of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 in LA hydrogenation to GVL. Scheme 1 shows the proposed synergy of paired Niδ+-Ni0 sites of S3M1.5@NiPS-600 in LA hydrogenation. 4 Conclusions In this study, we reported a carbothermal reduction method to prepare Ni catalysts derived from NiPS. Through the assistance of melamine addition, N can be immobilized on catalyst surface together with deposited carbonaceous species. The most active and stable catalyst showed a high GVL productivity (1387 mmol GVL/g surface Ni/h), a good recyclability (a 4.9% loss of initial activity in five cycles), and a negligible deactivation rate. Deposited carbonaceous species were found to improve catalyst stability while N-induced Niδ+ (δ>2) coupled with neighboring Ni0 sites were effective in the reduction of the ketone group of LA. This study ushers in a novel Ni catalyst design originated from carbothermally reduced NiPS and reveals its application in LA hydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Ni catalysts derived from the carbothermal reduction of nickel phyllosilicate were investigated and their application in the hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) was revealed. The most effective catalyst (S3M1.5@NiPS-600) was prepared by using a sucrose-melamine mixture (molar ratio = 2:1) as the reducing agent with a proper thermal treatment (maintained at 600 °C for 2 h). By using S3M1.5@NiPS-600, a high GVL productivity (1387 mmol GVL/g surface Ni/h), good recyclability (4.9% loss of initial activity in five cycles), and a negligible deactivation rate were observed. The promising outcome was attributed to grafted carbon and nitrogen species on the carbothermally reduced Ni/SiO2 catalyst.
